gcmin:kobellite	Kobellite	<https://www.mindat.org/1:1:2233:6>	02.HB.10a	Setterberg J (1841) Undersökning af ett nytt mineral, funnet uti Hvena Kobolt-grufvor uti Nerike, Kong. Svenska Vetenskaps-Akademiens Handlingar 1841, 188-193 Chemical formula is redefined to Pb_3_BiSbS_6_: Rammelsberg C F (1875) Kobellit, Handbuch der Mineralchemie 2, 100-101 The original chemical formula proposed by Setterberg is reconfirmed as Pb_6_Sb_2_Bi_4_S_15_: Keller H F (1890) Ueber Kobellit von Ouray, Colorado, und über die chemische Zusammensetzung dieser Species. Zeitschrift für Krystallographie und Mineralogie 17, 67-72 Chemical formula is redefined again as Pb_6_FeSb_2_Bi_4_S_16_: Nuffield E W (1948) Observations on kobellite, University of Toronto Studies: VI. Geological Series 52, 86-89 Chemical formula is redefined yet again as Pb_5_(Bi,Sb)_8_S_17_: Harris D C, Jambor J L, Lachance G R, Thorpe R I (1968) Tintinaite, the antimony analogue of kobellite, The Canadian Mineralogist 9, 371-382 Chemical formula is redefined again, based on crystal structure, Pb_12_(Cu,Fe)_2_(Bi,Sb)_14_S_35_: Miehe G (1971) Crystal structure of kobellite, Nature Physical Science 231, 133-134 Chemical formula redefined yet again: Moëlo Y, Roger G, Maurel-Palacin D, Marcoux E, Laroussi A (1995) Chemistry of some Pb-(Cu,Fe)-(Sb,Bi) sulfosalts from France and Portugal. gcmin:opal	Opal	<https://www.mindat.org/1:1:3004:1>	04.DA.10	Mineral name has been known since antiquity and predates any formal descriptive publication.  from mindat: Although it is still (2007) regarded as a valid mineral species for historical reasons, opal is not a true mineral in the accepted sense of the word as it is either composed of cristobalite and/or tridymite or composed of amorphous silica.  Opal is classified into four types: 1) Opal-CT: contains cristobalite-tridymite; 2) Opal-C: contains cristobalite; 3) Opal-AG: amorphous (Amorphous-Gel) (closely packed amorphous silica spheres form a diffraction grating to create precious opal); 4) Opal-AN: amorphous (Amorphous-Network (found as hyalite).  Transitions between opal-AG, opal-CT, and opal-C are common.	Si | O | H	hexagonal, tetragonal, amorphous	http://www.mindat.org/min-3004.html

Jambor J L, Puziewicz J (1990) New mineral names, American Mineralogist 75, 1209-1216 Calciovolborthite = tangeite, decided to change name to tangeite, because there is no formal relationship with volborthite.
